questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a nucleus of basal ganglia?
questions.explanation: The basal ganglia has five nuclei on each side of the brain. • Caudate nucleus • Putamen • Globus pallidus: Divided into globus pallidus external (GPe) and globus pallidus internal (GPi) • Substantia nigra: Divided into pars compacta and pars reticulata • Subthalamic nucleus The caudate nucleus and putamen together form the striatum. The putamen and globus pallidus collectively form the lentiform nucleus.

questions.question: Question 2: Which part of the basal ganglia receives the afferent input?
questions.explanation:
The striatum receives the afferent input. Note: There are two main inputs to the basal ganglia: From the cerebral cortex (corticostriate pathway) 
and from the thalamus (thalamostriate pathway). They are both excitatory (glutamate) and they 
both terminate in the striatum. The two major outputs of the basal ganglia are from GPi and substantia nigra. Both are inhibitory 
(GABAergic) and both project to the thalamus. From the thalamus, there is an excitatory (glutamatergic) projection to the prefrontal and 
premotor cortex. This completes the cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop. 313 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient is found to have a hemorrhage in the basal ganglia region. Which of the following is 
least likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient will have dysfunction of the basal ganglia. Maintenance of equilibrium is a function of 
the cerebellum and vestibular apparatus, hence will not be affected in this patient. Functions of basal ganglia: • Planning of movements • Regulation of muscle tone • Control of reflex muscular activity & posture • Programming of movement - speed, direction, and intensity • Role in the cognitive process (especially caudate nucleus)

questions.question: Question 6: Cells present in cerebellar cortex are all except
questions.explanation:
Bipolar cells are not present in cerebellum. Cerebellum has ê layers, ‘ deep nuclei and 5 types of neurons. The cerebellar cortex has three layers: • External molecular layer • Purkinje cell layer • Internal granular layer There are four deep nuclei: D,E,F,G • Dentate • Emboliform • Fastigial nuclei • Globose Interpositus nucleus- Globose and the emboliform nuclei together. There are five types of neurons in the cortex: • Purkinje • Granule • Basket • Stellate • Golgi cells 316

questions.question: Question 8: Efferent from cerebellar cortex is through which cell:
questions.explanation:
Purkinje cells are the only output neurons (efferent neurons) from the cerebellar cortex. The Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellum. Their axons, which are the only 
output from the cerebellar cortex, project to the deep cerebellar nuclei, especially the dentate 
nucleus, where they form inhibitory synapses.

questions.question: Question 9: Flocculonodular lobe has direct connections with
questions.explanation:
The flocculonodular lobe has connections with the vestibular apparatus. The flocculonodular lobe forms the vestibulocerebellum, which projects to the vestibular nuclei 
and is concerned with equilibrium and eye movements.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is correct?

options.b: Spino cerebellum constitutes vermis and lateral portion of cerebellar hemisphere
options.c: Vestibulo cerebellum constitutes nodulus and flocculus
options.d: Vestibulo cerebellum constitutes lateral portion of cerebellar hemispheres

questions.explanation:
Vestibulocerebellum (archicerebellum) constitutes nodulus and flocculus and is hence called 
floculonodular lobe. Spinocerebellum (paleocerebellum) constitutes vermis and adjacent medial portions of cerebellar 
hemispheres. Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) constitutes the lateral portions of hemispheres.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a function of the neocerebellum?

options.c: Planning and programming of voluntary movements

questions.explanation:
The function of the neocerebellum is planning and programming of voluntary movements. The cerebellum can be divided into: The Vestibulocerebellum/Archicerebellum: Consists principally of the flocculonodular lobe and 
adjacent portions of the vermis. It participates in balance, vestibular reflexes, and eye movements. The Spinocerebellum/Paleocerebellum: Consists of most of the vermis plus the adjacent 
intermediate zones on both sides of the vermis. It coordinates movements of the limbs. Vermis: 
Proximal muscles, Intermediate zones: Distal muscles The Cerebrocerebellum/neocerebellum: Consists of the large lateral zones of the cerebellar 
hemispheres. It receives all its input from the cerebral cortex (motor, premotor and 
somatosensory). It transmits its output back to the brain, functioning in a feedback manner to 
plan sequential voluntary body and limb movements.

questions.question: Question 13: A patient with a cerebellar lesion will show all of the following features except:
questions.explanation:
A patient with a suspected cerebellar lesion will not have resting tremors. Resting tremors are 
characteristic features of basal ganglia lesions. (Parkinson's disease). 318 
Sold by @itachibot Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases. Features of cerebellar disease • Ataxia – Incoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with drunken gait. • Hypotonia or atonia – Reduced or absence of muscle tone. • Dysmetria – Inability to judge the force and range of movement resulting in past pointing. • Dysdiadokokinesia – Failure to perform rapid alternating movements. • Decomposition of movement – Lack of smooth flow of movement. • Speech defect – Staccato speech or slurring speech. • Pendular knee jerk (a feature of hypotonia). • Intention tremors. • Nystagmus (jerky movements of the eye). • Rebound phenomenon.

questions.question:
Question 14: The vestibulo-ocular reflex is being performed in a patient with vertigo. Which of the 
following is associated with this reflex?
questions.explanation:
The vestibulo-ocular reflex is controlled by the vestibulo-cerebellum, which constitutes the 
flocculonodular lobe.

questions.explanation: The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory. However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.explanation: The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly. Note: The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory. However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is true?

options.a: Molecular layer contain stellate and basket cells
options.b: Molecular is the innermost layer of cortex
options.d: Axons of purkinje cell secrete Glutamate on deep cerebellar nuclei

questions.explanation:
The cerebellar cortex has three layers: External molecular layer: Contains Basket and Stellate Cells. 319 
Sold by @itachibot Purkinje cell layer: Only one cell thick, containing the purkinje cells. Internal granular layer: Contains Granule and Golgi Cells

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle 
highlighted in green in the image?
questions.explanation:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The anterior 
spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through it and terminates in both sides of the 
cerebellum. Dorsal spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and 
terminates on the same side as its origin.

questions.question:
Question 19: 311 
Sold by @itachibot Concerning the circuitry between mossy fibers, climbing fibers and cells of the cerebellar 
cortex, which of the following pairs provide excitatory input?

options.c: Granule cell parallel fibers and mossy fibers

questions.explanation:
The excitatory fibers in the cerebellum are climbing fibers, mossy fibers, and granule cell parallel 
fibers. The fundamental circuits of the cerebellar cortex : • Climbing fibers exert a strong excitatory effect on single Purkinje cells. Mossy fibers exert an 
excitatory effect on granule cells. • Each granule cell sends an axon to the molecular layer, where the axon bifurcates to form a T. 
The branches of the T are straight and run long distances; thus, they are called parallel fibers. The 
parallel fibers form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of many Purkinje cells. • The other neurons (basket cells, stellate cells, and golgi cells) are inhibitory interneurons. Basket 
cells and stellate cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and each inhibits many 
Purkinje cells. Golgi cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and mossy fibers. Their 
axons project to the dendrites of the granule cells where they form an inhibitory synapse. • The output of the Purkinje cells is ultimately inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.question: Question 20: Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of
questions.explanation:
Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of feedforward inhibition. Mossy fibers exert a weak excitatory effect on many Purkinje cells via the granule cells. The 
granule cells also excite the basket and stellate cells via their parallel fibers. The basket and 
stellate cells, in turn, inhibit the Purkinje cells (Feed forward inhibition). Renshaw cells exhibit feedback inhibition. 320
